185965713.review:
Ce jeu commençait bien , le jeu était payant donc moins de smurf, la compétition était quasi masterclass. Puis un jour, arriva une entreprise extrémiste pro-capitalisme, nommé Epic Games, qui décida de mettre le jeu gratuit, et changa le système des RLCS. Au début la première saison commençait bien, puis au début de la 2éme saison, Epic Games pense que c'est une bonne idée de baisser le MMR de tout les ranks du jeu et les serveurs commencèrent a être cataclysmique. Toute la communauté du jeu se plaignent mais Epic Games préfèrent mettre du caca dans leur oreilles pour ne pas écouter les idées de la communauté. Les problèmes de smurfing, serveurs et d'autre n'étaient toujours pas réglé par ces gérants frauduleux de Rocket League, le jeu mourrait de + en + rapidement. Puis un jour, vers 2022, on découvre que les serveurs peuvent être DDOS très facilement, comme si la sécurité a été mis en place par une équipe pakistanais/indien. La ranked était INJOUABLE, surtout dans les hauts élos, il y avait des DDOSEURS quasi à toute nos games. Les streameurs et joueurs signalent le problème horrible à Epic Games mais ces foutu chômeurs prenaient 3semaines a bannent les DDOSEURS. Puis quelque semaines après, une faille dans le jeu a été découvert afin d’être invisible pendant les parties, encore un autre problème montrant le travail HORRIBLE fait par ces extrémistes pro-capitalisme (ils ont pris 2mois a patch ce cheat et encore c'était la commu qui avaient trouvé un patch avant les developpeurs). Le DDOS était toujours pas patch, les joueurs pro en avait marre et le leaderboard n'avait plus aucun sens. Il y avait aussi le problème du wintrading (chose qui n'est toujours pas patch aujourd'hui donc n'importe qui peut être SSL s'il veut), des gens montaient des comptes a 3000MMR (j'en faisais parti honnêtement) et les serveurs de boosting utilisant le wintrade etaient de + en + nombreux. Les RLCS étaient donc de moins en moins regardé car le jeu était NUL, beaucoup de gens arrête le jeu à cause d'une dépression forte causé par Epic Games. Aujourd'hui, le 19/01/2025, le jeu est sur le bord de la fin, on a aucune idée de quand va sortir Unreal Engine 5 pour RL, et aucune bonne mise a jour sort depuis plusieurs mois. J'espère un meilleur avenir pour ce jeu qui étaient historique.
-Avis De YaYaMapping (alias Yanis).

185533055.review:
Rocket League – Frust auf Rädern und Nervenzusammenbrüche 

Rocket League klingt cool: Autos, Fußball, Chaos. In der Realität? Ein Albtraum auf vier Rädern. Die Server sind so stabil wie ein Kartenhaus im Orkan – Lags und Disconnects sind dein ständiger Begleiter. Manchmal scheint es, als würde der Ball nur dann reagieren, wenn das Internet mal kurz Mitleid hat.  

Dann der Battlepass: Absolut sinnlos. Du grindest stundenlang für Belohnungen, die aussehen, als hätte ein Dreijähriger sie entworfen. 

Und die Mitspieler? Ein Gedicht. Dein Team besteht entweder aus Spielern, die scheinbar mit der Stirn steuern, oder Egoisten, die den Ball nicht passen, weil sie unbedingt ihr TikTok-Highlight wollen. Selbst beim Gewinnen fühlt sich alles wie ein bitterer Sieg an, weil du eigentlich gegen alle – inklusive deiner eigenen Leute – kämpfen musst.  

Fazit: Rocket League ist mehr Chaos als Spaß. Server-Probleme, nutzlose Belohnungen und unfassbar schlechte Mates machen es zu einem Frustfest. 1,5 von 10 – der halbe Punkt ist dafür, als das Spiel noch gut war

185084359.review:
Rocket League Review: A Thrilling Fusion of Soccer and Cars… Until You Crash Into the Demolition Mechanic

Rocket League is an exhilarating game that takes the best of soccer and combines it with high-octane car battles, and the result is something truly special. The concept itself is ingenious: players control rocket-powered cars to score goals on massive fields, flipping and flying through the air to hit a giant soccer ball into their opponent’s net. The blend of sportsmanship, fast-paced action, and gravity-defying physics makes Rocket League one of the most unique and entertaining multiplayer experiences out there. Its accessibility, combined with deep mechanics, ensures that both casual players and seasoned veterans can have a blast, making it a staple in the gaming world.

Gameplay: A Fast-Paced, Addictive Experience
When you first launch Rocket League, it’s immediately clear that the game is built to be fun. The core mechanics are easy to pick up but hard to master, and the sense of speed and control you have over your car feels perfectly balanced. Whether you’re in a quick 1v1 match, playing with friends, or diving into ranked play, there’s always an adrenaline rush. The car movement feels fluid, and the aerial maneuvers, once you get the hang of them, can feel incredibly satisfying.

The game is incredibly intuitive at first. You start with basic car controls, like driving, boosting, and jumping, and gradually, you learn to chain these actions together for more complex moves like flips, fast aerial hits, and even saving goals from impossible angles. For many, the challenge is in mastering these mechanics—achieving the perfect aerial goal or stopping a ball that’s heading into the net with nothing but a well-timed boost.

The variety of game modes ensures that there’s always something fresh to try, whether it’s the traditional soccer mode or fun alternatives like Dropshot, Rumble, or even the seasonal variations that keep the gameplay from becoming stale. The matches are fast, typically lasting only a few minutes, which makes Rocket League an easy game to pick up and play during any free time.

The in-game progression system is also rewarding, with an endless variety of cosmetic items that allow players to customize their cars and showcase their personal style. The competitive ranked system adds a sense of achievement, and when you climb the ranks or pull off an impressive goal, it’s always a great feeling.

Rocket League is the perfect mix of simplicity and complexity, and it remains one of the best competitive experiences available today.

And Then... The Demolition Mechanic
But here’s where my enthusiasm takes a sharp turn for the worse. Let me be clear: Rocket League’s demolition mechanic is not only poorly designed; it’s downright frustrating. You might be thinking, "What could be so bad about the demolition feature? It’s part of the game’s identity!" Well, buckle up, because this aspect of the game is a nightmare wrapped in the form of an occasional satisfying explosion.

The concept behind demolitions is simple: when one car collides with another at high speed, both cars explode, causing a brief pause in play while you respawn and are sent back to the field. In theory, this could add some strategic depth to the game, offering an opportunity to eliminate an opponent for a few seconds. In practice, however, it’s often nothing more than an absurdly frustrating mechanic that disrupts the flow of the game.

Here’s the problem: demolitions feel completely random and are often triggered in the most ridiculous and nonsensical ways. I’ve lost count of how many times I've been cruising down the field, about to make a crucial save or score an important goal, when—bam!—I’ve been hit by a car I didn’t even see coming. And then, out of nowhere, my car explodes, and I'm left watching from the sidelines for a few seconds, unable to contribute. That split-second where I’m out of the game feels like an eternity, and all because I accidentally brushed up against an opponent who was in the middle of their own wild, out-of-control boost.

What makes this even worse is that the demolition mechanic is completely unpredictable. You can be in the middle of a perfectly normal maneuver, with your car facing away from the impact, and somehow, you’ll still be demolished. The game’s collision detection for demolitions is flawed at best, and it often seems like the car's hitbox is far more generous than it should be. You’ll collide with an opponent at an angle that doesn’t make any sense, and boom—instant explosion. It’s a mechanic that actively punishes you for no reason other than a fleeting moment of bad luck or a miscalculation in your car's trajectory.

And for what? A few seconds of respite for your opponent? It’s not like you're giving your team a chance to reposition, either. More often than not, you're eliminated just as your team is about to gain control of the ball or push forward to make a goal. So, you’re forced to sit on your hands, watching as your teammates try to hold the fort without you. It’s not fun, it’s not strategic, and more importantly, it’s just plain annoying.

The worst part? The demolition mechanic rarely feels earned. You might be hit by an opponent’s car in what feels like a perfectly reasonable situation. You’re not engaging in an aggressive, high-speed collision, but instead just going for the ball, only to get swept aside in some bizarre, random explosion. It’s a mechanic that too often turns matches into a chaotic mess of cars colliding in unpredictable ways. Instead of encouraging tactical play, demolitions often feel like cheap, frustrating moments of luck or pure nonsense that ruin the flow of the game.

To make matters worse, demolition-heavy gameplay can turn into an obnoxious loop. If one or two players on the opposing team start using demolition as a crutch, suddenly you’re stuck in a cycle of constant explosions. It’s not about playing soccer with cars anymore; it’s just about causing mayhem, and it feels cheap. It’s not a strategy—it's a gimmick, and it’s a gimmick that disrupts what could otherwise be a fast-paced, skillful game. You’ll watch in disbelief as your carefully orchestrated plays are interrupted for the umpteenth time by an opponent who isn’t interested in playing soccer—they’re just interested in racking up explosions.

It’s at this point that the demolition mechanic transforms from a fun, dynamic feature into a game-breaking annoyance. There are plenty of moments in Rocket League that feel rewarding, like when you nail a perfect aerial shot or set up a team goal, but there’s nothing satisfying about being randomly blown up after an innocuous collision. When the mechanic works, it’s fine, but when it doesn’t—and it often doesn’t—it kills any momentum the game might have built up.

Conclusion: Demolition Ruins Rocket League
Rocket League could be a perfect game if it weren’t for the demolition mechanic, which completely ruins the flow and fun. What should be a fast-paced, skillful experience is often interrupted by random explosions that make no sense, frustrate players, and add nothing meaningful to the gameplay. Instead of enhancing the game, it detracts from it in every way. Until Psyonix fixes this broken mechanic, Rocket League will remain an incredible game marred by an infuriating, unnecessary flaw. It’s a constant annoyance that drags down what could be one of the best multiplayer games out there.

Sources Cited
Smith, J. (2023). "The Unseen Mechanics of Rocket League: Demolitions and Why They Suck." Journal of Competitive Sports Gaming, 47(2), 98-105.
In this groundbreaking paper, Smith argues that the demolition mechanic in Rocket League is the main cause of its “frustration spike,” particularly in matches where players are “unfairly ejected” from the game.

Miller, A. (2022). "Explosive Failures: A Critical Examination of Demolition in Rocket League." Gaming Strategy Quarterly, 39(4), 76-82.

Если вы когда-либо мечтали о том, чтобы стать профессиональным водителем футбольного мяча, то Rocket League — это именно то место, где ваши мечты могут стать реальностью! Это игра, где ваши навыки вождения автомобиля и умение забивать голы соединяются в одну безумную смесь.

Сначала вы думаете: "Ну, это же просто футбол, только на машинах". Но потом вы понимаете, что ваши навыки вождения не дотягивают до уровня "первый раз за рулем". Вы начинаете с гордостью мчаться к мячу, а затем внезапно осознаете, что ваш автомобиль решил, что он — танк, и вместо удара по мячу вы просто врезаетесь в стену, как будто это ваша давняя обида.

И да, не забудьте про командную работу! Она важна, но когда ваши товарищи по команде начинают делать сальто и летать по воздуху, как будто это Олимпийские игры по акробатике, вы начинаете задумываться, не лучше ли было бы играть в шахматы.

А еще, когда вы забиваете гол, это чувство, когда ваш автомобиль взмывает в воздух, как будто он только что выиграл чемпионат мира, — просто непередаваемо! Но потом, когда вы понимаете, что это всего лишь игра, и ваш соперник уже ждет вас на другой стороне поля, чтобы отомстить, вы начинаете сомневаться в своем выборе.

В общем, Rocket League — это идеальное сочетание адреналина, смеха и, возможно, нескольких слез. Если вы хотите испытать, что значит быть водителем и футболистом одновременно, и при этом не бояться выглядеть как полный лузер, то эта игра для вас! 10/10, рекомендую всем, кто хочет почувствовать себя звездой футбольного поля... или просто посмеяться над своими неудачами.

184551886.review:
Rocket League isn’t just a game, it’s a full time job that doesn’t pay you and actively ruins your life and I mean that in the best way possible.

You start out thinking “Oh, this looks fun!” and next thing you know you’re up at 3 am telling yourself “Just one more match” like a liar. Sleep? Who needs it when there’s an open net waiting to be missed? My sleep schedule? Gone. My social life? In shambles. But hey I finally stopped hitting the crossbar every time so it’s totally worth it.

And relationships? Forget it. I’ve ignored texts, skipped plans, and even bailed on dinner just to queue comp. My mom asked me the other day “Do you even go outside anymore?” And I said “Only when I’m rotating back post, Mom. Chill” She wasn’t impressed.

Gameplay wise, Rocket League is the perfect mix of skill, strategy, and absolute chaos. Every match is a roller coaster of emotions from the thrill of nailing a clutch save to the heartbreak of own goaling because the ball decided to betray you, and don’t even get me started on teammates who think “rotations” are some kind of dance move.

Rocket League is frustrating, addicting, and the most fun I’ve ever had questioning my life choices. It’ll mess with your sleep, your relationships, and your sanity. My friends have even accepted that the only “team” I care about is the one I’m hard carrying in Ranked but somehow you’ll keep coming back and if you’re wondering where I spend most of my time, it’s not outside it’s on DFH Stadium.

11/10, would ruin my life for it again.

184316359.review:
I don’t know who woke up one day and said, “You know what soccer needs? Cars with rocket boosters,” but I want to personally thank them and also ask if they’re okay. Rocket League is the perfect blend of pure chaos and that "just one more game" addiction that ruins your sleep schedule and your relationships.

The game is simple: hit the ball into the goal. Easy, right? WRONG. Instead of gracefully kicking a ball, you’re piloting a rocket-powered car that’s harder to control than a shopping cart with one wobbly wheel. Half the time, I miss the ball completely and end up doing aerial donuts in the corner of the map like a confused circus act.

The skill curve in Rocket League is insane. In your first few matches, you feel like a god because you scored (accidentally, but still). Then, the game decides to casually match you against some dude named "AirBud69" who can juggle the ball across the entire field while performing aerial backflips and probably writing a novel at the same time. Humbling. Very humbling.

Customization is also wild. My car currently looks like a disco ball, complete with a taco hat and a trail of rainbow farts. Do these things help me play better? Absolutely not. But do they distract my opponents enough for me to score? Possibly.

The soundtrack is a certified banger. Honestly, I could lose every match and still walk away feeling like a winner because the EDM beats make me feel like I’m in a rave... that just so happens to have cars flying at my face.

My only real gripe? The physics. Who knew rocket cars would follow the laws of gravity? I was expecting Fast & Furious nonsense where I could drive up walls like Spider-Man, but no, I’m flipping upside down and face-planting into the ground every two seconds. Thanks, Isaac Newton.

In conclusion, Rocket League is the perfect game if you enjoy sports, explosions, and existential crises. Whether you’re scoring an epic goal or accidentally own-goaling while trying to show off, every match is a hilarious story waiting to happen. 10/10, would continue embarrassing myself.

184293448.review:
Rocket League: A Love-Hate Relationship Gone Sour

Rocket League, a game that once felt like the perfect mix of adrenaline-fueled competition and pure fun, has become a source of endless frustration for me. While the premise of rocket-powered cars playing soccer sounds exhilarating (and at times, it is), the game’s flaws often outweigh the fun. Here’s why I’ve grown to hate Rocket League:

1. The Steep Skill Ceiling
Rocket League is infamous for its high skill ceiling, which initially seems like a great challenge. However, after countless hours of grinding, the payoff feels minimal. For every flick or air dribble I manage to pull off, I’m met with players who demolish me effortlessly. The gap between “good” and “great” feels insurmountable, and it’s a constant reminder of how far I still have to go.

2. Toxicity Ruins the Game
No matter how well or poorly you play, the in-game chat is almost guaranteed to be a cesspool of toxicity. Teammates spam “What a save!” sarcastically the moment you make a mistake, and opponents throw shade after every goal. The community’s negative attitude makes the game stressful rather than enjoyable.

3. Unreliable Teammates in Ranked
One of the most infuriating aspects of Rocket League is its reliance on teammates in ranked mode. A single teammate who whiffs an open net, refuses to rotate, or decides to chase the ball everywhere can completely ruin a game. Worse, when you’re trying your hardest to rank up, being paired with uncooperative players feels like a slap in the face.

4. MMR System and Randomness
The matchmaking system feels like it punishes you rather than rewards you. One loss can send your MMR plummeting, while a win barely moves the needle. Some games feel entirely out of your control, with opponents leagues ahead of you in skill or teammates who seem like they’re still in tutorial mode.

5. Repetitive Gameplay
While Rocket League’s gameplay can be thrilling, it’s also repetitive. The matches blur together, and after a while, even scoring a great goal starts to feel hollow. Without significant updates or variety, the grind becomes monotonous.

Conclusion
Rocket League could have been the perfect game. It has all the elements of a masterpiece: fast-paced gameplay, high stakes, and a unique concept. But the toxicity, frustration, and seemingly endless grind suck the joy out of what should be a fun experience. If you enjoy being reminded of your flaws and dealing with toxic teammates, by all means, Rocket League is the game for you. For me, it’s become a source of stress I no longer want to deal with.

184153307.review:
I first purchased this game back in 2016, on Steam. For my first 600 or so hours I played keyboard only, windowed to about 1/2 of a 13in laptop screen - I was hooked. Rocket League feels more like playing sports than any other game. To this day no other game comes close to how hype I get scoring a goal, hitting a clutch save or coming back to beat a toxic opponent. 

Well, you can't get rocket league on steam anymore... This game has changed a lot and many people are worried about the future of RL. I've definitely played less and less as time has gone on specifically because of broken promises and decisions made by Epic. 

All that being said, I am not worried about Rocket League, not for a second. This player base takes no time off, constantly improving, inventing and perfecting new mechanics. Your 1000th win feels no less special than your 100th. I know every Saturday morning, I will be able to boot up RL, quick queue right into a toxic, "What a save!"ing, prepubescent, ball chasing, boost stealing, not going on kickoff teammate - and I wouldn't want it any other way. 

10/10 - highly recommend.

183665448.review:
[h1] Погружение на дно [/h1]
Все минусы игры описали и до меня, я лишь хочу добавить на счёт киберспортивной составляющей.
Следил за различными официальными турнирами и новостями по этой теме и стало очевидно, что как киберспортивная дисциплиина Rocket League облажалась по полной: 
[list]
    [*]Никакого разнообразия - стандарт 3vs3 и всё. (со следующего года конечно добавят 1vs1, но это самый худший выбор из всех вариантов)
    [*]Отсутствие конкуренции - за последние несколько лет доминируют постоянно одни и те же игроки из Франции. (кому захочется смотреть что-либо когда побеждают только французы? )
    [*]Геймплей упёрся в потолок и от про-игроков он превратился в пинг-понг и буст-менеджмент, играя в одну харю - смотреть такое откровенно не интересно.
[/list]
В целом подводя итоги можно сказать, что саму игру уже давно уничтожили, а насчёт игры как киберспорт, то её пора хоронить, ведь перспектив нет никаких и видя всё это безобразие киберспортивные организации бегут без оглядки)))
